newsitem.title: UK: Timing of BT, MCI talks seen favourable.
newsitem.headline: Timing of BT, MCI talks seen favourable.

text.p: Talks on a possible strategic merger between British Telecommunications Plc and MCI Communications Corp of the United States could be well timed, analysts said on Friday, although a number of obstacles stand in the way.
MCI had earlier confirmed that it was in discussions with BT, which already has a 20 percent stake in it, on establishing a "possible strategic merger".

Daiwa Europe Research analyst John Clarke said the timing for a move on MCI could be good, with potential U.S. rivals tied up by the need to restructure to cope with the opening up of the U.S. telecoms market.
"Certainly if they are going to, now is the time to do it because their cash-rich rivals have other fish to fry," he said.
Another analyst, who declined to be identified, said however that strict federal laws on foreign ownership of U.S. companies could stand in the way of a closer tie-up.
He added that a standstill agreement between the two companies on BT's 20 percent stake in MCI "is a long-term one with several years to run...That's another obstacle."
But he said that after BT invested in MCI "...it was clear if anyone were to invest further it would be BT.
He said the two companies' global corporate communications venture Concert "...is what they wanted out of the deal and that is progressing quite well."
MCI said on October 22 that Concert had $1.5 billion of revenues currently under contract and described it as an "unqualified success".
The analyst added that BT bought its stake in MCI at around $32 in 1993, paying a premium for the shares.
Daiwa's Clarke said a BT merger with MCI "would put all their eggs in the U.S. basket" and raise questions about BT's future intentions in the European telecoms market.
BT suffered a serious setback in September after German utility RWE severed links with BT to join a rival consortium led by Cable & Wireless Plc.
At the end of September it signalled its ambitions in the French market through a consortium involving Compagnie Generale des Eaux.
Trading in MCI shares was halted at 1832 GMT on Friday after a last trade of $27/1/4, up 5-5/8, pending a news announcement.
One analyst said he would have expected to see the MCI price spike up much higher than the $30 level on this news.
BT shares in London were unaffected by the news, which broke after the close of trading. BT shares closed down 4 pence at 355 1/2 pence.
However, BT's ADR traded in New York were down 1-5/8 at 56, off a low of 55-7/8 at 1944 GMT.
